comments: IAU new 2019Czech Republic proposal; a fictional substance in the novel Továrna na absolutno by Karel Čapek.
The name was originally Arabic: آخر النهر ʾāẖir an-nahr ('river's end').
Apparently first applied to η Cassiopeiae in the Skalnate Pleso Atlas of the Heavens published in 1950, but is not known prior to that.[14]
The traditional name of the β Scorpii system has been rendered Akrab and Elakrab, derived (like Acrab) from Arabic: العقرب al-ʿaqrab ('the scorpion').
"Acrux" is a modern contraction of the Bayer designation, coined in the 19th century, but which entered into common use only by the mid-20th century.[15][16]
The name was originally Arabic: الزبانى az-zubāná ('the claws').
Also called Aldhafera. The name is originally from Arabic: الضفيرة aḍ-ḍafīra ('the braid (or curl, or strand)' [of the lion's mane]).

The name is originally from Arabic: عذارى ʿaḏārá ('virgins'). In the Calendarium of Al Achsasi Al Mouakket, it is designated أول العذاري ʾawwil al-ʿaḏāriyy, translated into Latin as Prima Virginum ('first virgin').
The name was originally Arabic: الذيل aḏ-ḏayl (the train, lit. 'the tail').
The name is originally from Arabic: عين ʿayn ('eye') and was reviewed and adopted by the Working Group on Star Names.[5]
From Arabic: عين الرامي ʿayn ar-rāmī ('eye of the archer').
The name is originally from Arabic: الأظفر al-ʾuẓfur ('the talons' [of the swooping eagle]), shared with μ Lyrae (Alathfar).
The name is originally from Arabic: العناق الأرض al-ʿanāq al-ʾarḍ ('the caracal') (desert lynx).
IAU new 2019Cypriot proposal; first historically recorded name of Cyprus (mid-15th century).
The name is originally from Arabic: الأظفر al-ʾuẓfur ('the talons' [of the swooping eagle]), shared with η Lyrae (Aladfar).

The name is originally from Arabic: البلدة al-balda ('town'). In the Calendarium of Al Achsasi Al Mouakket, it is designated نير البلدة nayyir al-baldah, translated into Latin as Lucida Oppidi ('brightest of the town').
The name is originally from Arabic: البالع al-bāliʿ ('the swallower').
The source of the name Albireo is not entirely clear.[c]
From Arabic: الخباء al-ẖibāʾ ('tent'). In the Calendarium of Al Achsasi Al Mouakket, it is designated المنخر الغراب al-manẖar al-ġurāb, translated into Latin as Rostrum Corvi ('beak of the crow').
From Arabic: الخوار al‑ẖawwār ('the faint one').
Member of the Pleiades open star cluster (M45). Alcyone (Ancient Greek: Ἀλκυόνη Alkuonē) was one of the Pleiades sisters in Greek mythology.
The name was originally Arabic: الدبران ad-dabarān ('the follower' [of the Pleiades]).[18]
From Arabic: الذراع اليمين aḏ-ḏirāʿ al-yamīn ('the right arm' [of Cepheus]).
The name was originally الذنب aḏ-ḏanab ('the tail' [of the constellation of the Southern Fish]).
From Arabic: الضباع aḍ-ḍibāʿ ('the hyenas').
Shortening of Arabic: ذنب الدلفين ḏanab ad-dulfīn ('tail of the dolphin').
From Arabic: الفرق al-firq ('the flock'). Name given by Ulugh Beg to the asterism consisting of α, β and η Cephei.
From Arabic: الجدي al-jady ('the (male) kid'). Alternative traditional names are Al Giedi, Secunda Giedi and Algiedi Secunda.
From Arabic: الجانب al-jānib ('the flank'). Algenib is also another name for α Persei (Mirfak).
From Arabic: الجبهة al-jabha ('the forehead' [of the lion]).
From Arabic: رأس الغول raʾs al-ġūl ('head of the ogre'). In Egyptian, Horus.[clarification needed][19]
The traditional name Algorab is derived from Arabic: الغراب al-ġurāb ('the crow'). The WGSN re-designated the star as Algorab in July 2016.[2]
Derived from Arabic: الهنعة al-hanʿa ('the brand' [on the neck of the camel]).
Member of the Big Dipper or the Plough (UK).
Member of the Big Dipper or the Plough (UK).
From Arabic: النصل an-naṣl ('the point' [of the archer's arrow]).[20]
The middle star in Orion's belt.
The traditional name, alternately spelled Al Nitak or Alnitah, is from Arabic: النطاق an-niṭāq ('the girdle').[17]: 314–315
The name نير الفكة nayyir al-fakka ('bright (star) of the broken' [ring of stars]) is found in the Al Achsasi al Mouakket catalogue (c. 1650).[21]
From Arabic: الراقص ar-rāqiṣ ('the dancer'); also spelled Arrakis and Elrakis.
From Arabic: (النسر) الطائر (an-nasr) aṭ-ṭāʾir ('the flying' [eagle]).[citation needed] Altair is one of the vertices of the Summer Triangle asterism.
Alternately spelled Alzir.
IAU new 2019Nigerian proposal; named after Amadioha, a god in Igbo mythology.
IAU new 2019Philippines proposal. Named after Aman Sinaya, deity of the ocean and protector of fishermen in Tagalog mythology.
IAU new 2019Turkish proposal; refers to the motherland in Turkish culture.
The name is originally from Arabic: عرجة النهر ʿarjat an-nahr ('the bend of the river').[citation needed]
IAU new 2019Swedish proposal; name of a spaceship in Aniara, the eponymous poem by Harry Martinson.
Alternative traditional name is Lucida Anseris.
From Ancient Greek: Ἀντάρης Antarēs ('like Ares') (Mars).
IAU new 2019Andorran proposal; named after Vallnord, a peak in the north of the country.
The traditional name Arneb is from Arabic: أرنب ʾarnab ('hare').[17]: 268  (Lepus is Latin for hare.)
Part of the Teapot asterism.
Latin for 'first donkey colt'.
Latin for 'second donkey colt'.
Latin for 'third donkey colt'.
Member of the Pleiades open star cluster (M45). Asterope was one of the Pleiades sisters in Greek mythology.
IAU new 2019Togolese proposal; means 'the chain of the Atacora', a mountain range.
Member of the Pleiades open star cluster (M45). Atlas was the Titan of endurance and astronomy[22] and the father of the Pleiades sisters in Greek mythology.
Designated "Avior" by His Majesty's Nautical Almanac Office for the Royal Air Force in the 1930s.[23]
IAU new 2019Mexican proposal. An axolotl is a culturally significant amphibian; the name means 'water animal' in the Nahuatl language.
IAU new 2019Myanmar proposal; named after the Irrawaddy River.
Variously reported as from Arabic: السلحفاة as-sulaḥfāh ('turtle'), الطلف الفرس aṭ-ṭilf al-faras ('horse track'), or عزل الدجاجة ʿazal ad-dajāja ('tail of the hen').[17]: 192–197
Originally from Arabic: أدحي (النعام) ʾudḥiyy (an-naʿām) ('nest' [of the ostrich]); later miscopied as أرحى ʾazḥá in medieval manuscripts.
Alternatively rendered Asmidiske†.
IAU new 2019South Korean proposal; named after the highest mountain on the Korean peninsula.
Named after the American astronomer Edward Emerson Barnard, the first to measure its high proper motion.
The name is originally from Arabic: البيض al-bayḍ ('the eggs').
IAU new 2019Senegalese proposal; a rare source of water in the North.
IAU new 2019French proposal; named after Belenus, a god of light, the Sun and of health in Gaulish mythology.
Latin for 'female warrior'; applied to this star in the 15th century.[24]
IAU new 2019Ukrainian proposal. A deity of waters and riverbanks in Slavic religion; now a national goddess – "hearth mother, protectress of the earth".
Derived from Arabic: يد الجوزاء yad al-jawzāʾ ('the hand of') (an old asterism).
IAU new 2019Indian proposal; Bengali pronunciation of Sanskrit Vibha, meaning 'a bright beam of light'.
IAU new 2019Bosnia and Herzegovina proposal; name of the territory of Bosnia in the 10th century.
IAU new 2019Australian proposal; means 'child' in the Boonwurrung language.
IAU new 2019Ethiopian proposal; a commonly used word for coffee.
Ptolemy's Κάνωβος, after Canopus (Kanōpos, Kanōbos), a pilot from Greek mythology, whose name is itself of uncertain etymology.
The traditional name Capella ('small female goat') is from Latin, and is a diminutive of capra ('female goat').[17]: 86

The name is originally Arabic: كف kaff ('palm'), a residue of an old name of Cassiopeia, الكف الخصيب al-kaff al-ẖaḍīb ('the stained hand'); also known as السنام الناقة as-sanām al-nāqa ('the camel's hump').
IAU new 2019Uruguayan proposal; named after Erythrina crista-galli (the native tree that gives rise to the national flower).
Member of the Pleiades open star cluster (M45). Celaeno was one of the Pleiades sisters in Greek mythology.
IAU new 2015Named after Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra, the Spanish author of El Ingenioso Hidalgo Don Quixote de la Mancha (Don Quixote).[25]
IAU new 2015Named after Chalawan, a mythological crocodile king from a Thai folktale.[25]
IAU new 2019Thai proposal; named after the Chao Phraya River.
IAU new 2019Slovakian proposal; an ancient Slovak term for the Sun.
IAU new 2019Tunisian proposal; a taqiyah (traditional hat) and national headdress.
Alternative traditional name Chort.
IAU new 2019Haitian proposal; named after Citadelle Laferrière, a mountaintop fortress and UNESCO World Heritage Site.
IAU new 2019El Salvadorian proposal; means 'river of stars' in the Nawat language.
IAU new 2019Nicaraguan proposal; named after Lake Nicaragua.
IAU new 2015In honor of the astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus.[25]
Named after Charles I of England by Sir Charles Scarborough.[17][26][27]
Traditional name, variously spelled Kajam.
The name is originally from Arabic: الكرسي al-kursiyy ('the chair, footstool').

The name is originally from Arabic: ذنب الدجاجة ḏanab ad-dajāja. In Chinese, Deneb is part of the 鵲橋 ('Magpie bridge') in the Qi Xi love story.[citation needed] Deneb is one of the vertices of the Summer Triangle asterism.
IAU new 2019Trinidad and Tobago proposal; means 'to dance, twist and turn', symbolising the national ancestral culture and language.
Arabic for 'frog', from the phrase ضفدع الثاني aḍ-ḍifdaʿ aṯ-ṯānī 'the second frog' (the 'first frog' is Fomalhaut)
IAU new 2019Costa Rican proposal; means 'the Sun' in the Bribri language.
IAU new 2019Mauritian proposal; named after an oil lamp used on special occasions, including Diwali.
IAU new 2019Indonesian proposal; means 'our star' in the Nias language.
IAU new 2019Russian proposal; named after the Dombay resort region in the North Caucasus.
Member of the Big Dipper or the Plough (UK).
From the traditional name of Dziban or Dsiban, derived from Arabic: الذئبانِ aḏ-ḏiʾbān ('the two wolves' or 'the two jackals').[17]: 212
IAU new 2019Syrian proposal; named after Ebla, an early kingdom in Syria.
Common name reviewed and adopted by the Working Group on Star Names.[5]
Member of the Pleiades open star cluster (M45). Electra was one of the Pleiades sisters in Greek mythology.
Variously El Nath or Alnath, from Arabic: النطح an-naṭḥ ('the butting') (i.e. "the bull's horns").

Alternative traditional name of Etamin; both originally from the Arabic constellation name التنين at-tinnīn ('the great serpent'). γ Dra was also one of the "Five Camels" (Latin: Quinque Dromedarii), in Arabic العوائد al‑ʿawāʾid.
IAU new 2019Mozambique proposal; represents love in the Makhuwa language.
IAU new 2015
IAU new 2015Named after a Norse mythological dwarf who turned into a dragon.[25]
From the Chinese name 房 Fáng ('the room').
IAU new 2019Cuban proposal; named after Félix Varela, a noted science teacher.
IAU new 2019Italian proposal. Named after Phlegethon, an underworld river of fire in Greek mythology in the poem Divina Commedia (The Divine Comedy) by Dante Alighieri.
IAU new 2015The name is originally from Arabic: فم الحوت fum al-ḥawt ('mouth of the fish'). In Persian astrology, this star was called "Haftorang, Watcher of the South", one of the royal stars.
IAU new 2019Chinese Taipei proposal; Latin: Formosa ('beautiful') is a historical name for Taiwan.
IAU new 2019Austrian proposal; named after Franz Joseph I of Austria.
From the Chinese name 附路 Fùlù ('the auxiliary road').
IAU new 2019Icelandic proposal; an Old Icelandic word meaning 'fire' or 'blaze'.
From the Chinese name Fu Yue.
The name "Gacrux" is a contraction of the Bayer designation, coined by astronomer Elijah Hinsdale Burritt (1794–1838).[28][29]
IAU new 2019Bhutan proposal; means happiness.
Its colour was described as "garnet" by William Herschel. Following Herschel, it was called garnet sidus by Giuseppe Piazzi.
Traditional name, variously spelled Gianfar.
Also known as Gienah Gurab; the star ε Cygni is also traditionally known as Gienah.[citation needed]
Traditional name in the culture of the Wardaman people of the Northern Territory of Australia.[30]
IAU new 2019British proposal; means 'to shine (like a star)' in the Manx Gaelic language.
Italian for 'claws'; also once applied to β Scorpii.[31][17]: 367
IAU new 2019Brunei[32] proposal; a Malay language word referring to a magical stone found in snakes or dragons.

Traditional name (also written Hemal, Hamul, or Ras Hammel) derived from Arabic: رأس الحمل raʾs al-ḥamal ('head of the ram'), in turn from the name for the constellation as a whole, al-ḥamal ('the ram').[17]: 78, 80
IAU new 2015Latin for 'the Helvetian' and refers to the Celtic tribe that lived in Switzerland during antiquity.[25]
IAU new 2019Algerian proposal; named after the Hoggar Mountains.
IAU new 2019Finnish proposal; the name of hell or the underworld in Finnic mythology.
IAU new 2019Honduran proposal; one of the Maya Hero Twins who became the Sun in K'iche' Maya mythology.
IAU new 2019Hungarian proposal; named after the Hunor, one of the legendary ancestors of the nation.
IAU new 2019Albanian proposal; named after the Illyrians, the people from whom Albanians are descended and what they call themselves.
IAU new 2015Intercrus means 'between the legs' in Latin, referring to the star's position in the constellation Ursa Major.[25]
IAU new 2019Peruvian proposal; a character in the story Way to the Sun by Abraham Valdelomar.
IAU new 2019Malaysian proposal; means 'diamond' in the Malay language.
IAU new 2019Slovenian proposal; a character in the novel Under the Free Sun by Fran Saleški Finžgar.
IAU new 2019Gabonese proposal; means 'all that is beautiful' in the Myene language.

Originally from Arabic: إزار ʾizār ('veil') In the Calendarium of Al Achsasi Al Mouakket, it is designated منطقة ألعوع minṭaqat al‑ʿawwaʿ, translated into Latin as Cingulum Latratoris ('belt of barker'). Named Pulcherrima ('most beautiful') by Otto Struve.[33]
IAU new 2019Kenyan proposal; means a very strong whirling column of wind in the Dholuo language.
IAU new 2019Japanese proposal; a word denoting Kamuy, a supernatural entity in the Ainu language.
From the Chinese name 亢 Kàng ('the neck').
IAU new 2019New Zealand proposal; word for a local plant that produces orange fruit in the Māori language.
Part of the Teapot asterism.
The top of the Teapot asterism.
Part of the Teapot asterism.
IAU new 2019Iranian proposal; named after Kāve, a hero of the epic poem Shahnameh composed by Ferdowsi.
IAU new 2019Puerto Rican proposal; means 'star' in the Taíno language.
IAU new 2019Estonian proposal; means 'dawn' in the Estonian language.
A modern (19th century) name, due to Angelo Secchi.
Traditional name in the culture of the Wardaman people of the Northern Territory of Australia.[30]
IAU new 2019Greek proposal; named after Lerna, the lake where the mythical Hydra lived.
IAU new 2015Latin for 'liberty' (Aquila is Latin for 'eagle', a popular symbol of liberty).[25]
IAU new 2015A neutron star and pulsar with planets. A lich is a fictional undead creature known for controlling other undead creatures with magic.[25]
IAU new 2019Latvian proposal; means 'fire' and is the name of a character in the poem Staburags un Liesma.
IAU new 2019Hong Kong proposal; named after Lion Rock, a culturally important lion-shaped peak.
IAU new 2019Luxembourger proposal; named after the Fortress of Luxembourg built in 963 by Count Siegfried, the founder of Luxembourg.
IAU new 2019Portuguese proposal; ancient name for Lusitania, the region where most of Portugal is situated.
IAU new 2019Colombian proposal; named after a mythical village from the novel Cien anos de soledad (One Hundred Years of Solitude) by Gabriel García Márquez.
IAU new 2019German proposal; named after Mago National Park, a national park in Ethiopia noted for its giraffes (Camelopardalis is Latin for 'giraffe').
IAU new 2019Azerbaijani proposal; named after the poet Mahsati Ganjavi.
Member of the Pleiades open star cluster (M45). Maia was one of the Pleiades sisters in Greek mythology.
IAU new 2019Aruban proposal; the indigenous name given to Palm Beach, a beach and popular snorkelling spot.
The name is originally from Arabic: المرفق al-mirfaq ('the elbow').[citation needed]
IAU new 2019Dominican Republic proposal; the god of drought and protector of the Sun.
IAU new 2019Mongolian proposal; a name given to the Gobi bear.
Member of the Big Dipper or the Plough (UK).
Traditional name deriving from Arabic: الميسان al-maysān ('the shining one').
Derived from Arabic: منخر manẖar ('nostril'), or al‑minẖar ('nose' [of Cetus]).[34][17]: 162
Member of the Big Dipper or the Plough (UK).
Member of the Pleiades open star cluster (M45). Merope was one of the Pleiades sisters in Greek mythology.
Also bore the alternative historical name "Becrux", a modern contraction of the Bayer designation.[35]
Alternately spelled Minelava.
The right-most star in Orion's belt. The name Mintaka itself is derived from Arabic: منطقة manṭaqa ('belt').[17]: 314–315
Latin for 'wonderful' or 'astonishing'; named by Johannes Hevelius in his Historiola Mirae Stellae (1662).

Member of the Big Dipper or the Plough (UK). The name is originally from Arabic: المئزر al-miʾzar ('apron, waistband, girdle'). Also called 禄 Lù ('Status'), one of the "Three Stars" in Chinese mythology. The Lù star is believed to be Zhang Xian, who lived during the Later Shu dynasty. The word lù specifically refers to the salary of a government official. As such, the Lù star is the star of prosperity, rank, and influence.
IAU new 2019Romanian proposal; named after Moldoveanu Peak, the highest peak in Romania.
IAU new 2019Swiss proposal; named after Mönch, a prominent Alpine peak in Switzerland.
IAU new 2019Panamanian proposal; a traditional dancing costume.
IAU new 2019Serbian proposal; named after the Great Morava river system.
IAU new 2019Palestinian proposal; ancient name for Temple Mount in Jerusalem.
IAU new 2019Burkina Faso proposal; named after the Black Volta, the largest river.
IAU new 2019Tanzanian proposal; named after Dalbergia melanoxylon, a tree whose ebony wood is used for musical instruments.
Alternative traditional spelling of Mufrid.
IAU new 2015Latin for 'music' (the ancient Greek musician Arion's life was saved at sea by dolphins (delphinus) after attracting their attention by playing his kithara).[25]
IAU new 2019Danish proposal; named after the Norse mythological realm of fire Muspelheim.
IAU new 2019South African proposal; means 'star' in the Sesotho, SeTswana and SePedi languages.
Along with brighter star γ2 Sagittarii (Alnasl), it makes up the spout of the Teapot asterism.
IAU new 2019Norwegian proposal; means 'star' in the Sámi language.
IAU new 2019Zambian proposal; means 'thank you' in many national languages.
"Navi" is a modern name, due to Gus Grissom (his middle name "Ivan" spelled backward).
IAU new 2019Ecuadorian proposal; means 'the Sun' in the language of the Waorani tribes.
IAU new 2019Belgian proposal; adapted from Nervii, a Celtic tribe.
IAU new 2019Canadian proposal; means 'mother' in the Cree language.
IAU new 2019Argentinian proposal; means 'spring' in the Moqoit language.
Along with τ Sagittarii, it makes up the handle of the Teapot asterism.
IAU new 2019American proposal; named after the Nushagak River in Alaska.
IAU new 2019Ivory Coast proposal; named after the supreme creator deity of Akan religion.
IAU new 2015Named after Ogma, a deity in Celtic mythology.[25]
IAU new 2018
IAU new 2019Singaporean proposal; the name is Latin for 'little lion'.
Designated "Peacock" (after the constellation) by His Majesty's Nautical Almanac Office for the Royal Air Force in the 1930s.[23]
IAU new 2019Jordanian proposal; Named after Petra, the archaeological city and UNESCO World Heritage Site.
A member of the Big Dipper or the Plough (UK). Alternative traditional names are Phekda or Phad.
IAU new 2019Lebanese proposal; named after Phoenicia, the ancient civilisation.
IAU new 2019Chilean proposal; named after Pincoya, a female water spirit from local mythology.
IAU new 2019Liechtenstein proposal; named after a bright and visible butterfly in the local dialect of Triesenberg.
Member of the Pleiades open star cluster (M45). Pleione was the mother of the Pleiades sisters in Greek mythology.
IAU new 2019Cook Islands proposal; means a large mystical black pearl in the Cook Islands Māori language.
Became known as stella polaris ('polar star') during the Renaissance.[9]: 23  See polar star for other names based on its position close to the celestial pole.
See South Star.
Ancient Greek: προκύον prokuon ('preceding the Dog') (viz. Sirius); Latinized as Antecanis.
The nearest star to the Sun.
IAU new 2015Named after Rán, the Norse goddess of the sea.[25]
IAU new 2019Malagasy proposal; the name of a giant creature from folklore.
Also spelled Ras Algethi.
Also spelled Ras Alhague.
Also known as Suhail and Suhail al Muhlif, which also apply to λ Velorum (Suhail).
Latin for 'prince' or 'little king'. Regulus was known to Persian astrologers as "Venant, Watcher of the North", one of the royal stars.

Traditional name first recorded in the Alfonsine Tables of 1252 and derived from the Arabic name الرجل الجوزاء اليسرى ar-rijl al-jawzāʾ al-yasrá ('the left leg (foot) of Jauzah'[definition needed]) (rijl meaning 'leg, foot').[17]: 312–313
The name is originally from Arabic: رجل قنطورس rijl qantūris ('foot of the centaur').
IAU new 2019Spanish proposal; named after the writer Rosalía de Castro.

The name appeared in Piazzi's Palermo Star Catalogue in 1814, added by Niccolò Cacciatore as a prank along with Sualocin (α Delphini); "Rotanev" is Venator, the Latin form of Italian: Cacciatore ('hunter'), spelt backwards.

Derived from Arabic: ركبة rukba ('knee').[36] The alternative historical name Ksora appeared in a 1951 publication, Atlas Coeli (Skalnate Pleso Atlas of the Heavens) by Czech astronomer Antonín Bečvář; professor Paul Kunitzch has been unable to find any clues as to the origin of the name.[9]: 62
IAU new 2019Nepalese proposal; the Nepali name for the world's highest peak (Mount Everest).
Traditional name from Arabic: سیف الجبار sayf al-jabbār, literally 'saif ('sword') of the giant'.[37]
IAU new 2019Sri Lankan proposal; means 'peace' in the Sinhala language.
IAU new 2019Maltese proposal; a mythological giant from Maltese folk tales.
Formerly "p Sceptri" in the constellation of Sceptrum Brandenburgicum.

Also traditionally bore the name Schedir; both originally from Arabic: صدر ṣadr ('breast'); also called الضاة الكرسي aḍ-ḍāh al-kursiyy ('the lady in the chair' by Ulugh Beg, whence[clarification needed] Dath Elkarti by Giovanni Battista Riccioli in 1651.
From an erroneous transcription of Seginus, the traditional name for γ Boötis.[38]
A mistranscription of the Arabic form of Boötes.[citation needed]
IAU new 2019Pakistani proposal; an Urdu literary term meaning 'a small lamp or flame'.
IAU new 2019United Arab Emirates proposal; named after Sharjah, the cultural capital and city of knowledge of the UAE.
IAU new 2019Ghanaian proposal; means 'gold' in the Ewe language.

Ancient Greek: Σείριος 'the scorcher'; in Egyptian Sopdet, rendered in Greek as Σῶθις Sōthis. As the brightest star in the sky, Sirius has proper names in numerous cultures, including Polynesian (Māori: Takurua; Hawaiian: Ka'ulua ('Queen of Heaven'), among others). Also known as the "Dog Star".
IAU new 2019Polish proposal; named after Solaris, a novel by Stanisław Lem.

Other traditional names are Azimech, from Arabic: السماك الأعزل as-simāk al-ʾaʿzal ('the undefended') and Alarph, Arabic for 'the grape gatherer'. Known in Indian astronomy as Chitra ('the bright one').
IAU new 2019Dutch proposal; named after The Starry Night by Vincent van Gogh.

IAU new 2019Croatian proposal; named after Stribog, the god of winds in Slavic mythology. Stribor is also a character in the book Priče iz davnine (Croatian Tales of Long Ago) by Ivana Brlić-Mažuranić.

The name appeared in Piazzi's Palermo Star Catalogue in 1814, added by Niccolò Cacciatore as a prank along with Rotanev (β Delphini); "Sualocin" is Nicolaus, the Latin form of Italian: Niccolò ('Nicholas'), spelt backwards.
Traditionally, this name also applied to γ Velorum (Regor).
IAU new 2019Lithuanian proposal; means 'peace' in the Lithuanian language.
From the Chinese name 太陽守 Tàiyángshǒu ('guard of the Sun').
From the Chinese name 太乙 Tàiyǐ or 太一 Tàiyī ('the great one'), both of which refer to Tao.
Also called Talitha Borealis, as Talitha originally referred to κ Ursae Majoris (Alkaphrah) and ι Ursae Majoris together.[citation needed]
IAU new 2019Bulgarian proposal; named after Tengri, the god early Bulgars worshiped.
IAU new 2019Bolivian proposal; means 'Milky Way' in Guarani.
Alternative traditional spelling of Tarazet.
Member of the Pleiades open star cluster (M45). Taygete was one of the Pleiades sisters in Greek mythology.
Alternative traditional name of Tegmen.
Traditional name, also called Tejat Posterior.
From Ptolemy's τετράπλευρον tetrapleuron ('quadrilateral'), a group of four stars of which ω Sagittarii is the brightest.[citation needed]
IAU new 2019Israeli proposal; means 'world' or 'universe' in the Hebrew language.
Also written as Theemim or Beemin.
In Chinese, 天關 Tiānguān ('celestial gate'). Also reported as Akkadian: Shurnarkabti-sha-shūtū ('the star in the bull towards the south' or 'the southern star towards the chariot').[17]: 391
From the Chinese name 天乙 Tiānyǐ or 天一 Tiānyī ('the Celestial Great One'), a deity in Taoism.
IAU new 2019Bangladeshi proposal; means 'darkness' in the Bengali language.
IAU new 2019Moroccan proposal; named after Tislit Lake and means 'the bride' in the Amazigh language. Associated with a heartbroken girl in legend.
IAU new 2015Named after the settlement in northern Morocco and UNESCO World Heritage Site now known as the medina (old town) of Tétouan.[25]
IAU new 2019Guatemalan proposal; the Tohil (patron deity) of the K'iche' Maya.
The name is originally from Arabic: ظليمان ẓalīmān ('two (male) ostriches').
IAU new 2015Named after Tonatiuh, the Aztec god of the Sun.[25]
IAU new 2019Irish proposal. The aunt of the warrior Fionn mac Cumhaill of Irish legend.[citation needed]
IAU new 2019Paraguayan proposal; Tupã is the name of God in the Guarani language.
IAU new 2019Brazilian proposal; named after the indigenous Tupi people.
IAU new 2019Pitcairn Islands proposal. Aklen means 'we/us' in the Pitkern language.
From Arabic: عنق الحية ʿunuq al-ḥayya ('the serpent's neck'), called Cor Serpentis ('Heart of the Serpent') in Latin.
IAU new 2019Iraqi proposal; named after Uruk, an ancient city of Sumer and Babylonia in Mesopotamia.

The name is originally from Arabic: النسر الواقع an-nasr al-wāqiʿ ('the alighting vulture') also translated as vulture cadens ('falling vulture') (see also Aetos Dios, Stymphalian birds). As the second brightest star in the northern sky, Vega has names in numerous cultures. In Chinese, it is known as 織女 ('weaving girl') from the Qi Xi love story. Vega is one of the vertices of the Summer Triangle asterism.
IAU new 2015Latin for 'where there is truth'.[25]
Vindemiatrix is Latin for '(female) grape gatherer'.
A traditional name in the culture of the Wardaman people of the Northern Territory of Australia.[30]
IAU new 2019Nanjing proposal; Xihe is the goddess of the Sun in Chinese mythology. The star also represents the earliest Chinese astronomers and makers of calendars.[citation needed]
From the Chinese name 玄戈 Xuángē ('sombre lance').
From yildiz, Turkish for 'star'.
Traditional name, alternatively spelled Zaurac; originally from Arabic: زورق zawraq ('boat').[17]: 218
From the Chinese name 張 Zhāng ('extended net').
Rana is Latin for 'frog'.
